description: Uncertain. Suggestions include connection with Old Irish cuäch (“cup, goblet, bowl; cauldron, large vessel; bowl, cup”) (whence Scots quaich, queff). The noun is derived from the verb.

entries.meaning: The act of quaffing; a deep draught. [from late 16th c.]

verbs.description: quaff (third-person singular simple present quaffs, present participle quaffing, simple past and past participle quaffed)

entries.meaning: To drink or imbibe with vigour or relish; to drink copiously; to swallow in large draughts. [from mid-16th c.]
examples: I can't believe you quaffed four pints of beer and could still drive!
